EatingWell
Where Good Taste Meets Good Health GET UPDATES FROM EatingWell Like 1k How Many Slices of Bacon Does Your Dinner Equal? 3 Restaurant Shockers Posted: 04/ 8/11 07:25 AM ET React Amazing Inspiring Funny Scary Hot Crazy Important Weird Read more Hilary Meyer , Bacon , Calories , Dinner , Eating Well , Eatingwell , Restaurant Meals , Slidepollajax , Food News
share this story
By Hilary Meyer, EatingWell Associate Food Editor
The last hotel I stayed in had an awesome breakfast buffet. Yogurt, fruit, granola, eggs, bacon... you name it, they had it. And like a consciously healthy eater, I loaded my plate with fruit and yogurt and daintily added 2 strips of bacon. Even though I work as an associate food editor at EatingWell Magazine, and spend a great deal of time in our test kitchen developing healthy recipes, I can't deny my love for bacon. But seeing the white juicy veins of fat running between the layers of "meat" and curling up around the ends of each glorious strip tells me that bacon is something to enjoy in moderation. That's why when we develop recipes in the EatingWell Test Kitchen that use bacon, we use it sparingly.
I've got bacon's nutritional profile memorized: 1 medium strip of bacon has 43 calories and 1.1 grams of saturated fat. I also am aware that the American Heart Association recommends limiting intake of saturated fats to less than 7 percent of daily calories. (That's 16 grams, if you're consuming 2,000 calories.) That's because saturated fats raise levels of LDL ("bad") cholesterol in the blood, damaging the heart and arteries, triggering inflammation that may eventually leading to a heart attack or stroke. Hmmm. That bacon's not looking so good after all. 9 "Bad" Foods You Should Be Eating
Fast-forward a couple of hours and I'm starving. My husband and I ended up at Chili's and he suggested splitting an order of the Shiner Bock BBQ Ribs. Not that I thought ribs are a health food, but I was shocked to learn that a full order of those succulent ribs has 1,750 calories and 29 grams of saturated fat. So, if I were to order and eat that dish by myself, it would have the same amount of saturated fat as 26 strips of bacon. I could have cleared out the entire tray of bacon at breakfast for what I would have gotten from those ribs. (By the way, I ended up ordering salmon.)
That got me thinking how funny it was that I would never consider having more than 2 strips of bacon on my plate at breakfast, but I would certainly (unknowingly) entertain the thought of eating a dish that had the saturated fat equivalent of 15, 20, even 30 strips of that smoky goodness. So like some people carry around tip calculators, I'm carrying around my own mental bacon calculator--that is, I'll be figuring out how many strips of bacon fit into the meal I want to order and if the answer results in a giant heap, I think I'll pass and look for something better. Or better yet, make it healthier at home.
Here are some menu items at a few popular restaurants and how much bacon you'd have to eat to get the same amount of saturated fat, plus some healthier alternatives and recipes you can make at home. By Hilary Meyer, EatingWell Associate Food Editor
EatingWell Associate Food Editor Hilary Meyer spends much of her time in the EatingWell Test Kitchen, testing and developing healthy recipes. She is a graduate of New England Culinary Institute.
Follow EatingWell on Twitter: www.twitter.com/eatingwell

Karl_Wilder: Why would anyone eat at either Chili's or Olive Garden http://www.huffingtonpost.com/social/Karl_Wilder/how-many-slices-of-bacon-is-your-dinner_b_846354_83861935.html History | Permalink | Share it garystartswithg el sueno de la razon produce republicans 1038 Fans 06:40 PM on 04/10/2011 for a lot of people chilis olive garden and unos are whats for dinner -- most of suburban america depends on them. i wouldn't even be able to tell you where one was near me because they just don't fly in my neck of the woods. i would say its an urban vs suburban thing, but its not 100%. garystartswithg: for a lot of people chilis olive garden and unos http://www.huffingtonpost.com/social/garystartswithg/how-many-slices-of-bacon-is-your-dinner_b_846354_83967958.html History | Permalink | Share it This comment has been down-ranked into oblivion. Loading comments… klbrz 167 Fans 11:09 PM on 04/08/2011 Maybe it's just me (been known to happen), but the person who wants to order the chicken and shrimp carbonara at olive garden, is just not going to be happy with the venetian apricot chicken. If those were my two choices, I'd have to go with the carbonara, sans the chicken and shrimp (a carbonara dish is *almost* too rich with just pasta, no need to pile on all that other stuff), or go home. The pizza substitutes seem okay, but the example of, no, I'll take the salmon, not the ribs, is a little unrealistic, also.
I guess I don't eat out as much as others (maybe once or twice a month), because I don't really understand these kinds of articles that say don't eat this yummy fattening thing from this restaurant, order this bland, uninspiring pile of yuck that you will leave half of. When I eat out, I tend to not worry about calories or fat, etc. It's supposed to be a treat, not another exercise in guilt. Then again, if I ordered the ribs from Chili's, I know there would be plenty of leftovers for another meal or two. That's a lot of food. klbrz: Maybe it's just me (been known to happen), but the http://www.huffingtonpost.com/social/klbrz/how-many-slices-of-bacon-is-your-dinner_b_846354_83801467.html History | Permalink | Share it This comment has been down-ranked into oblivion. I work hard on my blog to demonstrate that being healthy doesn't mean being deprive all the time. And yes, those two strips of bacon aren't going to be the end of your waistline.
